Issues.Title: Accessibility Extended Diagnostics: Ensure that aria-* attributes are valid on the element based on its aria role
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

Extended Diagnostics

### Description

WCAG maps the valid ARIA attributes based on a given aria role. We can ensure that aria-* attributes are valid on the element based on it’s role. Googlers see: [a map of valid aria](http://go/a11y-analyzer-rules#allowed-attributes-by-role).

### Proposed solution

A new Accessibility Extended Diagnostic can provide developers guidance on valid aria-* attributes.

Base case: DOM primitives and native HTML elements with known aria-role
Inferred case: @Component() and @NgModule() with declarative API’s which can infer the aria-role
Stretch: Nested @Component() and @NgModule() or <ng-content> with an unknown aria-role

### Alternatives considered

This is an extension from the ideas in https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/44869 for A11y validation.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Accessibility Extended Diagnostics: Ensure that aria-* attributes are valid on the element based on its aria role" (#46673)

Issues.Title: Detect missing imports in standalone components
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

compiler

### Description

If a directive has an attribute selector and the attribute is used without square brackets, such as `routerLink="/users"`, and we forget to import the directive, or the module defining the directive, then the compiler doesn't complain at all, and we end up with an unnoticed bug.

When using NgModules, such a bug happens rarely, because you rarely forget to import the router module (for example) in your main or feature module. But when using standalone components, it's much more frequent, because the import needs to be repeated on every component that needs the directive, and of course we tend to only import what's absolutely needed.

After migrating two relatively small applications to standalone components, I've introduced such a bug, especially with routerLink, at least twice. 

I understand why the compiler doesn't complain, but this, IMHO, is a source of hard to detect bugs: I doubt most people have integration tests checking that each and every link in their components works as expected. And even at runtime, the bug goes unnoticed until you click on the link and realize it doesn't work.


### Proposed solution

It would be nice to be able to activate some compiler option that would, for example, check that any non-standard HTML attribute used in a component (such as `routerLink`) matches with a known directive selector for that component.

Or to be able to provide a list of selectors or attributes that must be checked.

### Alternatives considered

I don't see any.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Detect missing imports in standalone components" (#46661)

Issues.Title: New Simple Built in State Management Package
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

In the angular ecosystem there are many fantastic state management solutions, but the Angular framework does not have a built in solution except perhaps the tools needed to put one together (rxjs, BehaviourSubject etc), which is challenging for beginners as they would already have to spend a decent amount of time learning rxjs to use and understand those tools correctly.

I think it would benefit angular to have an @angular/state package, since angular is supposed to be an all in one package for frontend development it makes sense that state management would be included, other js libraries include some form of simple state management built in.

It would also be a way for beginners to be introduced to state management in a beginner friendly way before choosing to adopt 3rd party solutions i.e ngrx, ngxs, akita etc.

### Proposed solution

Provide a simple and easy to maintain state management package.

I used this once [observable-store](https://github.com/danwahlin/observable-store.) and I think it would fit quite nicely as it was very simple to learn, the only major caveat is that it is still observable based, however it might be easier to grasp what's going on due to abstracting away some complexity. Although I think it might have non observable methods or be converted into a promise based solution if desired.



### Alternatives considered

Continue to rely on 3rd party solutions.

Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

Atm the naming of the mdc-button is (mostly) the same as in the current/legacy `mat-button`

However, the buttons in https://m3.material.io/components/buttons/overview have different names:
- [Elevated button](https://m3.material.io/m3/pages/common-buttons/guidelines/#4e89da4d-a8fa-4e20-bb8d-b8a93eff3e3e)
- [Filled button](https://m3.material.io/m3/pages/common-buttons/guidelines/#9ecffdb3-ef29-47e7-8d5d-f78b404fcafe)
- [Filled tonal button](https://m3.material.io/m3/pages/common-buttons/guidelines/#07a1577b-aaf5-4824-a698-03526421058b)
- [Outlined button](https://m3.material.io/m3/pages/common-buttons/guidelines/#3742b09f-c224-43e0-a83e-541bd29d0f05)
- [Text button](https://m3.material.io/m3/pages/common-buttons/guidelines/#c9bcbc0b-ee05-45ad-8e80-e814ae919fbb)

But the current `mdc-button` implementation (still) uses: ` button[mat-button], button[mat-raised-button], button[mat-flat-button],button[mat-stroked-button]`

Wouldn't it be more logical to use the same naming as https://m3.material.io?

Issues.Title: bug(datepicker): closing datepicker on monthSelected shows day view briefly
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

At least 8.2.3

### Description

Sometimes you might want to have a datepicker that, at its lowest level, selects a month and then closes. My use-case is that I am on a view with a calendar on a view showing an entire month. Since I am showing a month, picking a day is irrelevant

To get around the datepicker going to a day view when clicking on a month, you can add a function that runs on the `(monthSelected)` event and calls `datepicker.close()` when fired. This works, but it flashes the day view for a split second before closing. It should just close right away.

### Reproduction

Use the example at the very bottom of the official Material docs for the datepicker:
https://material.angular.io/components/datepicker/examples


### Expected Behavior

Use this example that uses Angular Material 8.2.3
https://stackblitz.com/angular/ekjvrbglvnb?file=src%2Fapp%2Fdatepicker-views-selection-example.ts

The datepicker closes immediately upon selecting a month. 

This is just one that I found when researching this issue. It is possible that versions later than this also work.

### Actual Behavior

The datepicker switches to the day view and then closes.

### Environment

- Angular: 14.0.2
- CDK/Material: 14.0.2
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(datepicker): closing datepicker on monthSelected shows day view briefly" (#25191)

Issues.Title: bug(FocusMonitor): cdk-program-focused on mouse click
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

10.2.7

### Description

When user mouse clicks a checkbox/radio button/slide toggle with a mouse (not keyboard, not programatically), the clicked element contains **cdk-program-focused** class instead of **cdk-mouse-focused** (it always has cdk-focused which is correct). I want to use this cdk-program-focused CSS class to draw special visible focus for accessibility purposes but I don't want this special CSS visible for mouse clicks. **cdk-keyboard-focused** works flawlessly without any issues when user focuses checkbox/radio button/slide toggle with keyboard (even with NVDA on).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/48152706/176430437-5854e4c6-409f-4769-8162-73ba1a6d9c33.png)


I don't know the logic behind this so maybe this was done by design to avoid some accessibility issues with focus monitoring.
Is this by design? It used to work in Material v10.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Navigate to the demos at https://material.angular.io/components/checkbox/overview or https://material.angular.io/components/radio/overview
2. Mouse Click the demo radio button/checkbox so it is checked
3. Open browser DevTools and find the element that you just clicked and look for CSS classes it contains


### Expected Behavior

cdk-mouse-focused should be present in the element, not cdk-program-focused when user clicked the element with a mouse

### Actual Behavior

cdk-program-focused is present in the element instead of cdk-mouse-focused

### Environment

- Angular: 14.0.3
- CDK/Material: 14.0.3
- Browser(s): Chrome/Firefox/Edge
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10 Pro, Version 21H2 (OS Build 19044.1766)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(FocusMonitor): cdk-program-focused on mouse click" (#25188)
